context: [2] In contrast, the ETR in IE plants remained stable or became even slightly increased, possibly due to increased leaf temperatures during HDSs (; ).  [3] Different tolerance of ETR in IE and NE Grey poplar upon abiotic (heat and light) stress has been reported previously (; ).  [4] ETR reflects the quantum yield of PSII and provides information about the light reaction of photosynthesis and CO2 assimilation .  [5] Because ETR is thylakoid membrane localized, reduced ETR in heat-stressed NE plants may be explained as a consequence of altered membrane stability (; ) and/or of direct interaction of isoprene with reactive oxygen species, resulting in lower oxidative damage and lipid peroxidation (; ; ).  [6] Recent findings by , ) suggest that the lower ETR in NE plants may result from subcellular remodeling processes that occur in NE chloroplasts, possibly as a consequence of the RNA interference-mediated silencing of the ISPS.  [7] The analysis of the chloroplast ultrastructure, the proteome, and the lipid composition of the thylakoid membrane of IE and NE poplars  revealed a comprehensive structural and functional reorganization in the thylakoid membranes of NE plants. llm_generation.summary: In this context, 2-methylbuta-1,3-diene (isoprene) is discussed in relation to its potential protective effects against oxidative damage and lipid peroxidation in plants under abiotic stress. The interaction of isoprene with reactive oxygen species may help stabilize thylakoid membranes, thereby reducing lipid peroxidation, which is a key indicator of oxidative stress in plant cells. This suggests a significant role of isoprene in mitigating oxidative damage, linking it directly to lipid peroxidation processes.
